posts.name: A-Frame
posts.note: A-Frame is a creative Asian and international flavors mix at this hip eatery with communal tables and patio dining. You need to try the baby back ribs, and beer can chicken. If you're there on Sunday get the all-you-can-eat chicken which consists of three types of chicken, fries, corn, and Hawaiian buns.

posts.name: Azla Ethiopian Vegan
posts.note: Azla Ethiopian Vegan is a casual, cheery counter-serve with small tables specializing in vegan renditions of Ethiopian dishes.

posts.name: Batter Fish Food Truck
posts.note: Most locals agree that BatterFish food Truck serves the best fish and chips in LA. Even better, this bright yellow truck usually serves their famous seafood on the scenic streets of Santa Monica. Make sure to try the homemade tartar sauce on their fresh fish. For something different give the chili catfish a go.

posts.name: Bludso's Bar & Que
posts.note: Bludso's Bar and Que is a sit-down outpost of a local Texas BBQ joint offering classic meats and sides, plus creative cocktails.

posts.name: Blue Star Donuts
posts.note: Blue Star Donuts is a minimalist cafe for grab-and-go brioche donuts in grown-up flavors such as blueberry-bourbon-basil and the best apple fritter I have ever had in my life and I'm in my mid 50's. Couldn't believe there is now a few Blue Star Donuts in the Los Angles area. You need to try one of their apple fritters, but any of their donuts will not steer you wrong. NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Cassell's Hamburgers
posts.note: Cassell's Hamburgers is a burger joint in the Hotel Normandie offering breakfast and classic American fare in a diner setting. You need to order the patty melt or the breakfast sandwich which is between two hash brown patties with avocado.

posts.name: Chego West
posts.note: Chego West serves spicy rice bowls and other Korean-Mexican eats. The humble little LA-in-a-rice bowl restaurant full of win and the color orange set out to reinvigorate the rice bowl. Slow roasted prime rib with creamed horseradish, or sticky-sweet slabs of Berkshire pork belly over hot rice and fried egg.

posts.name: chi SPACCA
posts.note: chi SPACCA serves meaty, upscale Italian fare from a trio of star chefs in a Tuscan atmosphere with worn-wood tables.

posts.name: Church and State
posts.note: Church and State is a rustic-chic bistro serves house-made charcuterie and other French classics, plus creative cocktails. When you're there, you should order a charcuterie plate. The more people you have, the more variety or items you will get on the plate.

posts.name: Grand Central Market
posts.note: Grand Central Market is a grand emporium hosting food vendors and florists, plus game nights, movies and other events, since 1917.

posts.name: Horse Thief BBQ
posts.note: Horse Thief BBQ is located in the Grand Central Market window is offering smoked meats and gourmet sides, plus outdoor seating. You need to order the smoked pork belly or the southern fried chicken sandwich.

posts.name: Intelligentsia Coffee
posts.note: Intelligentsia Coffee is a high-end coffee bar chain is serving daily roasted brews in an industrial-chic setting. They have a great dark chocolate hot chocolate and espresso (four shots). Great atmosphere to have a relaxing cup of coffee, tea, etc. while getting some work done or reading a book. NOTE: They have multiple locations.

posts.name: Kogi BBQ
posts.note: Kogi BBQ first rolled out as the little Korean-taco-truck-that-could, peddling $2.00 Korean barbecue tacos on the streets of L.A. Little did they know that within a few short months, they would become an icon of LA street food, a roving symbol of rebellion, independence and the belief that excellent food can be had on a dime budget. NOTE: They have multiple trucks that move around the city.

posts.name: La Brea Bakery Cafe
posts.note: La Brea Bakery Cafe is popular for its handmade bread, this casual cafe serves sandwiches, soup, and other light fare.

posts.name: Leo's Tacos Truck
posts.note: Leo's Tacos Truck has delicious Al Pastor tacos are better than ever with a taste that will leave you wanting more. You can order them by the plate full which most people do. The beef head, tripe, Lengua (tongue), etc. are outstanding too.

posts.name: The Little Jewel of New Orleans
posts.note: The Little Jewel of New Orleans is part grocery store, part deli, this laid back spot imports culinary treats from New Orleans located in Los Angles Chinatown. You need to order the pork Po' Boy sandwich or the crawfish mac and cheese.

posts.name: Locol
posts.note: Conscientious fast-food spot with a simple design for breakfast, burgers and health-oriented options.

posts.name: Monti Carlo
posts.note: Dive Bar in Koreatown.

posts.name: Myung in Dumplings
posts.note: Myung in Dumplings makes traditional Korean buns and dumplings offered in a simple, subdued eatery with a pictorial menu. They make some of the best dumplings I have ever eaten. My favorites were the spicy steam roll dumpling with pork, the boiled dumpling with pork, and the fried dumpling with shrimp.

posts.name: Original Pantry Cafe
posts.note: Casual cash-only diner, open since 1924, dishes up ample portions of American eats around the clock. You need to try the chicken fried steak or the pork chop breakfast specials if they have them.

posts.name: Osteria Mozza
posts.note: Lauded upscale Italian cuisine from chefs Nancy Silverton and Mario Batali in a bustling atmosphere.

posts.name: Pizzeria Mozza
posts.note: Nancy Silverton and Mario Batali turn out acclaimed wood-burning-oven pizzas and antipasti in busy digs.

posts.name: Rutt's Hawaiian Cafe
posts.note: Rutt's Hawaiian Cafe is a restaurant with sidewalk seating serving traditional comfort eats plus Hawaiian menu options.

posts.name: Salt and Straw
posts.note: Popular ice cream chain out of Oregon known for inventive flavors and farm-sourced ingredients. All their flavors are great it all depends on what you're in the mode to eat. My favorite is their Sea Salt with Caramel Ribbons in a cup.

posts.name: Simmzy's
posts.note: Bustling, open-air pub with a rotating selection of craft beers and American eats, including burgers.

posts.name: Sunny Spot
posts.note: Sunny Spot is a colorful, funky, modern Caribbean joint, crafting inventive cocktails and jerk wings. It's another Roy Cho place.

posts.name: Super Tortas D.F.
posts.note: No-frills mobile eatery is doling out Mexican tortas stuffed with layers of meats, cheese, and eggs. Found out about this place while standing line for spit roasted al pastor.

posts.name: Swadeah
posts.note: The bare-bones establishment is offering South Asian groceries and cafeteria-style Bangladeshi eats.

posts.name: Tavern On 2
posts.note: Tavern On 2 is a lively gastropub is offering farm-fresh bites and a rotating menu of 50 craft beers and wines in warm digs. The dishes to order is pig tails and the short rib poutine.

posts.name: Tofu House (Beverly Soon Tofu)
posts.note: Traditional Korean dishes including more than ten combinations of flavors of soon tofu, barbecued galbi, bulgogi, spicy chicken, spicy squid, tofu steak, and the stone plate bibimbap. You need to get the spicy tofu soup to put over rice.

posts.name: Venice Ramen
posts.note: Venice Ramen is a compact, simple Japanese eatery for house-made noodles in a range of broths, plus other specialties. No need for extra noodles since they give you so many to start with I forced my way through them. The two types of dumplings they serve are great too.
